author: sky.cactus
content: My Geth + Lodestar node just finished filling my 2TB drive.  Does Geth have any options that will make it take less space these days?  <insert rant about Ethereum needing to care more about nodes being operable by end-users>

author: greystroke
content: Switch to Ethrex EL.  Only takes 460GB fully synced

author: greystroke
content: https://ethrex.xyz/

author: greystroke
content: Having said that, enable history expiry in Geth and then prune or resync

author: potuz
content: you can wipe history, I'm far below 2TB today with geth + Prysm, doubt Lodestar's dbase is larger than Prysm's

author: potuz
content: I'm using 1.2T today

author: potuz
content: `--state.scheme=path` and `--prune-history` are what you want

author: potuz
content: this will prune the pre-merge history (not sure if they already shipped rolling history pruning or not)

author: sky.cactus
content: 1.3TB for Geth, wiping history dropped that just below 1TB.  A 2 "TB" drive is ~1.7TB in actual usable disk, so 1.3TB for Geth plus 400GB for Lodestar is sufficient to push one over the edge.  I'm guessing I'll be right back in this situation again in some number of months, but this time without the easy ability of deleting pre-merge data.

author: sky.cactus

author: sky.cactus
content: Having my node blow out its disk and needing to manually fix it every few months is why I eventually stopped running Nethermind.  If I end up having to do that with Geth too I'll probably just stop running Ethereum nodes and join the masses in using one of 3 centralized service providers.

author: greystroke
content:
Stop being do dramatic!
First,  a resync will give you more data back than a prune. 
Second, try Ethrex,  only 460gb fully synced and only takes 2 hours to sync.
Third,  4tb is pretty cheap nowadays.  Or buy a 2nd 2tb and run in raid 0
Fourth, plug in a USB or hdd or nas on the lan and move ancient data to there

author: __flcl
content:
Hello! There is an option to automatically prune nethermind's state when there is not a lot of space. it also constantly prunes history now, so should be better than before. More info:
- pruning https://docs.nethermind.io/fundamentals/pruning/#storage-left-threshold 
- history expiration https://docs.nethermind.io/fundamentals/history-expiry

author: sky.cactus
content: I had pruning enabled but it still was running out of space.  I don't think I had automatic history expiry (wasn't an option at the time) but I didn't download history so my history only went back to last sync.
